subject: Sleep
title: Paradoxical Insomnia
description: A short lesson to help you apply Paradoxical Insomnia.

hook.text: A patient insists they haven't slept in three days. The sleep lab recording shows seven hours per night.

buildup.text: This is paradoxical insomnia, also called sleep state misperception. The person genuinely believes they're awake.

discovery.text: Brain scans show these patients have elevated wake-like activity during sleep, blurring the boundary.

twist.text: Their suffering is real. The subjective experience of not sleeping causes the same daytime impairment.

climax.text: The brain can sleep and feel awake simultaneously. Consciousness isn't a clean on-off switch.

punchline.text: You can sleep for hours and genuinely not know it.

quiz.question: What is paradoxical insomnia?
options: Believing you're awake when sleep lab data shows you slept
